attributes.title: Multivariate analysis
attributes.description: Can GMD predict internalizing or externalizing scores

q1.value: Structural correlates of psychopathology in children

q3.value:
Typical child behavior can encompass a wide range of actions. While a certain degree of idiosyncrasy is expected, childhood misbehavior can be an indication of insufficient development of essential skills in emotional and behavioral regulation. The goal of this study is to identify patterns in brain gray matter structure which may underlie internalizing and externalizing symptoms in children between the ages of 4 and 12. First, a multivariate analysis will assess if gray matter density can predict internalizing or externalizing scores as compared to age and brain size.  Second, mixed effects linear models will be used to elucidate specific associations between gray matter density, psychopathology, age, and head size. Previous work in this age range has shown associations between internalizing and externalizing symptoms and structural and functional differences in the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, temporal cortex, prefrontal cortex, parietal cortex, hippocampus, and parahippocampus. (Whittle, 2019; Ameis, 2014; Bick, 2017; Cabeen, 2018; Sato, 2016; Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012)

Internalizing symptomology has been implicated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex (Whittle, 2019) but cross-sectional studies have found reduced cortical thickness in this region (Merz, 2018). These studies have also shown associations between increasing internalizing symptoms and decreased cortical thickness in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Merz, 2018), decreased hippocampal volume (Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012), and increased pallidal volume (Merz, 2018).

Increased externalizing symptomology has been associated with reduced cortical thinning in the postcentral gyrus (Whittle, 2019), decreased cortical thickness in the orbitofrontal cortex, retrosplenial cingulate, and medial temporal cortex (Ameis, 2014), as well as decreased cortical thickness in the frontal pole, rostral middle frontal gyrus, and pars orbitalis (Merz, 2018).

q4.value: The development of emotional and behavioral regulation skills is a critical component of typical child growth. Substantial deficits in these skills can contribute to lifelong challenges in managing behaviors. Based on previous work, we hypothesize these data will show reduced cortical thickness associated with increased internalizing symptomology in the orbitofrontal cortex and prefrontal cortex, decreased volume in the hippocampus, and increased volume in the pallidum. We expect associations in cortical thickness associated with externalizing symptoms in the orbitofrontal cortex,  cingulate cortex, and temporal cortex, and pars orbitalis. We expect the mixed-effects linear model to show age-related differences in cortical thinning such that increased internalizing symptomology is associated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex and increased externalizing symptomology is associated with reduced thinning in the postcentral gyrus.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Processing and quality control of imaging data is conducted independently of behavioral data analysis.

question.value: This study employs a cross-sectional secondary analysis of data.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data in this study have been collected from 7 different studies, which did not have primary aims to examine brain structure and psychopathology.

question.value: Participants were recruited from the Pittsburgh area via research databases, community flyers, and word of mouth referrals, as well as from clinics to participate in one of seven studies. Participants were compensated approximately $25/hour. Exclusion criteria differed for each study. Contraindication for MRI or neurological disorders, developmental delays, or the inability to complete computer games and other research tasks excluded ineligible participants. Inclusion criteria mandated understanding of conversational English. Data were collected beginning in 2012 and continued through 2019. Participants came into the laboratory to complete an MRI scan while watching a movie or TV show and/or responding to computer tasks with a response device. All participants practiced in a mock scanner to help with familiarization with the environment.

q13.value: 270 unique children provided between 1 and 2 anatomical MRI scans. 142 children ages 4-11 comprise the sample.

q14.value: Previous work from Koolschijn, et al. in 2012 found hippocampal volume to be associated with internalizing symptoms in 8-17 year olds (Pearson's r=-0.26).  Based on those results, a minimum sample of 113 children are needed to detect a similar effect size.  Our sample of 142 children is large enough to detect a small to medium effect size of 0.23 based on power analyses run in R using the pwr library.

question.value:
Variables of interest include: age, internalizing problems, externalizing problems, total problems, and gray matter density. 
Variables of non-interest include: estimated intracranial volume and sex

1. Multivariate analysis
a. Use GMD to separately predict internalizing, externalizing, and total scores

2. Mixed effects linear model -- assess if GMD be predicted by age, internalizing/externalizing/total scores, main effects of age and internalizing/externalizing/total
a. GMD  ~ intercept+ age + symptomology + eICV + sex (random) effect
b. GMD  ~ intercept+ age + symptomology + Age*symptomology + eICV + sex (random) effect

q20.value:
Imaging data are processed using an N4 bias correction to account for non-uniformity in image intensity.  Gray matter density is then estimated from tissue contrast based on a set of sample-specific tissue priors.

Internalizing, externalizing, and total problems are likely to be skewed since the subjects are largely a normative sample. Thus, these data will be log transformed using a Yeo-Johnson power transform to normalize the distribution while preserving the rank order.

q21.value: This study will compare effects sizes (Pearson's R) as well as model fit indices (BIC, AIC, or MSE) as appropriate. Clusters will be characterized using p-values and t-statistics.

q22.value: All data was visually inspected before being included in the model. MRI data: visual inspection of MPRAGE can lead to removal. If after estimating GMD field maps do not fit individual brain, data can be removed.

q23.value: Behavioral data is subjected to thresholds for ASEBA software to account for skipped survey questions. Response scores were imputed if only one question was omitted in a given CBCL category, and categories with multiple omitted responses did not generate scores. One participant left a response blank in the internalizing category, and one omitted a response in the externalizing category, but none omitted multiple responses in the internalizing or externalizing sub-fields. Analyses were conducted including these imputed values in behavioral data.

q24.value: Possible associations with total symptomology or age. Follow-up analyses include model fitting procedures to see if removing variables could create a model with a better fit.

registration_responses.q3:
Typical child behavior can encompass a wide range of actions. While a certain degree of idiosyncrasy is expected, childhood misbehavior can be an indication of insufficient development of essential skills in emotional and behavioral regulation. The goal of this study is to identify patterns in brain gray matter structure which may underlie internalizing and externalizing symptoms in children between the ages of 4 and 12. First, a multivariate analysis will assess if gray matter density can predict internalizing or externalizing scores as compared to age and brain size.  Second, mixed effects linear models will be used to elucidate specific associations between gray matter density, psychopathology, age, and head size. Previous work in this age range has shown associations between internalizing and externalizing symptoms and structural and functional differences in the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, temporal cortex, prefrontal cortex, parietal cortex, hippocampus, and parahippocampus. These studies have also shown associations between increasing internalizing symptoms and decreased cortical thickness in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Merz, 2018), decreased hippocampal volume (Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012), and increased pallidal volume (Merz, 2018).

Increased externalizing symptomology has been associated with reduced cortical thinning in the postcentral gyrus (Whittle, 2019), decreased cortical thickness in the orbitofrontal cortex, retrosplenial cingulate, and medial temporal cortex (Ameis, 2014), as well as decreased cortical thickness in the frontal pole, rostral middle frontal gyrus, and pars orbitalis (Merz, 2018).

attributes.title: Mixed effects linear model
attributes.description: Y_i  ~ β_o+ β_1 P_x+ β_2age+ β_3∗age+age∗P_x+ β_4sex_random      Can GMD be predicted by age, internalizing/externalizing, main effects of age and internalizing/externalizing?

Internalizing symptomology has been implicated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex (Whittle, 2019) but cross-sectional studies have found reduced cortical thickness in this region (Merz, 2018). These studies have also shown associations between increasing internalizing symptoms and decreased cortical thickness in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Merz, 2018), decreased hippocampal volume (Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012), and increased pallidal volume (Merz, 2018).

Increased externalizing symptomology has been associated with reduced cortical thinning in the postcentral gyrus (Whittle, 2019), decreased cortical thickness in the orbitofrontal cortex, retrosplenial cingulate, and medial temporal cortex (Ameis, 2014), as well as decreased cortical thickness in the frontal pole, rostral middle frontal gyrus, and pars orbitalis (Merz, 2018).

q4.value: The development of emotional and behavioral regulation skills is a critical component of typical child growth. Substantial deficits in these skills can contribute to lifelong challenges in managing behaviors. Based on previous work, we hypothesize these data will show reduced cortical thickness associated with increased internalizing symptomology in the orbitofrontal cortex and prefrontal cortex, decreased volume in the hippocampus, and increased volume in the pallidum. We expect associations in cortical thickness associated with externalizing symptoms in the orbitofrontal cortex,  cingulate cortex, and temporal cortex, and pars orbitalis. We expect the mixed-effects linear model to show age-related differences in cortical thinning such that increased internalizing symptomology is associated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex and increased externalizing symptomology is associated with reduced thinning in the postcentral gyrus.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value: Processing and quality control of imaging data is conducted independently of behavioral data analysis.

question.value: This study employs a cross-sectional secondary analysis of data.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data in this study have been collected from 7 different studies, which did not have primary aims to examine brain structure and psychopathology.

question.value: Participants were recruited from the Pittsburgh area via research databases, community flyers, and word of mouth referrals, as well as from clinics to participate in one of seven studies. Participants were compensated approximately $25/hour. Exclusion criteria differed for each study. Contraindication for MRI or neurological disorders, developmental delays, or the inability to complete computer games and other research tasks excluded ineligible participants. Inclusion criteria mandated understanding of conversational English. Data were collected beginning in 2012 and continued through 2019. Participants came into the laboratory to complete an MRI scan while watching a movie or TV show and/or responding to computer tasks with a response device. All participants practiced in a mock scanner to help with familiarization with the environment.

q13.value: 270 unique children provided between 1 and 2 anatomical MRI scans. 142 children ages 4-11 comprise the sample.

q14.value: Previous work from Koolschijn, et al. in 2012 found hippocampal volume to be associated with internalizing symptoms in 8-17 year olds (Pearson's r=-0.26).  Based on those results, a minimum sample of 113 children are needed to detect a similar effect size.  Our sample of 142 children is large enough to detect a small to medium effect size of 0.23 based on power analyses run in R using the pwr library.

question.value:
Variables of interest include: age, internalizing problems, externalizing problems, total problems, and gray matter density. 
Variables of non-interest include: estimated intracranial volume and sex

1. Multivariate analysis
a. Use GMD to separately predict internalizing, externalizing, and total scores

2. Mixed effects linear model -- assess if GMD be predicted by age, internalizing/externalizing/total scores, main effects of age and internalizing/externalizing/total
a. GMD  ~ intercept+ age + symptomology + eICV + sex (random) effect
b. GMD  ~ intercept+ age + symptomology + Age*symptomology + eICV + sex (random) effect

q20.value:
Imaging data are processed using an N4 bias correction to account for non-uniformity in image intensity.  Gray matter density is then estimated from tissue contrast based on a set of sample-specific tissue priors.

Internalizing, externalizing, and total problems are likely to be skewed since the subjects are largely a normative sample. Thus, these data will be log transformed using a Yeo-Johnson power transform to normalize the distribution while preserving the rank order.

q21.value: This study will compare effects sizes (Pearson's R) as well as model fit indices (BIC, AIC, or MSE) as appropriate. Clusters will be characterized using p-values and t-statistics.

q22.value: All data was visually inspected before being included in the model. MRI data: visual inspection of MPRAGE can lead to removal. If after estimating GMD field maps do not fit individual brain, data can be removed.

q23.value: Behavioral data is subjected to thresholds for ASEBA software to account for skipped survey questions. Response scores were imputed if only one question was omitted in a given CBCL category, and categories with multiple omitted responses did not generate scores. One participant left a response blank in the internalizing category, and one omitted a response in the externalizing category, but none omitted multiple responses in the internalizing or externalizing sub-fields. Analyses were conducted including these imputed values in behavioral data.

q24.value: Possible associations with total symptomology or age. Follow-up analyses include model fitting procedures to see if removing variables could create a model with a better fit.

registration_responses.q1: Structural correlates of psychopathology in children
registration_responses.q3:
Typical child behavior can encompass a wide range of actions. While a certain degree of idiosyncrasy is expected, childhood misbehavior can be an indication of insufficient development of essential skills in emotional and behavioral regulation. The goal of this study is to identify patterns in brain gray matter structure which may underlie internalizing and externalizing symptoms in children between the ages of 4 and 12. First, a multivariate analysis will assess if gray matter density can predict internalizing or externalizing scores as compared to age and brain size.  Second, mixed effects linear models will be used to elucidate specific associations between gray matter density, psychopathology, age, and head size. Previous work in this age range has shown associations between internalizing and externalizing symptoms and structural and functional differences in the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, temporal cortex, prefrontal cortex, parietal cortex, hippocampus, and parahippocampus. (Whittle, 2019; Ameis, 2014; Bick, 2017; Cabeen, 2018; Sato, 2016; Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012)

Internalizing symptomology has been implicated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex (Whittle, 2019) but cross-sectional studies have found reduced cortical thickness in this region (Merz, 2018). These studies have also shown associations between increasing internalizing symptoms and decreased cortical thickness in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (Merz, 2018), decreased hippocampal volume (Merz, 2018; Koolschijn, 2012), and increased pallidal volume (Merz, 2018).

Increased externalizing symptomology has been associated with reduced cortical thinning in the postcentral gyrus (Whittle, 2019), decreased cortical thickness in the orbitofrontal cortex, retrosplenial cingulate, and medial temporal cortex (Ameis, 2014), as well as decreased cortical thickness in the frontal pole, rostral middle frontal gyrus, and pars orbitalis (Merz, 2018).

Substantial deficits in these skills can contribute to lifelong challenges in managing behaviors. Based on previous work, we hypothesize these data will show reduced cortical thickness associated with increased internalizing symptomology in the orbitofrontal cortex and prefrontal cortex, decreased volume in the hippocampus, and increased volume in the pallidum. We expect associations in cortical thickness associated with externalizing symptoms in the orbitofrontal cortex,  cingulate cortex, and temporal cortex, and pars orbitalis. We expect the mixed-effects linear model to show age-related differences in cortical thinning such that increased internalizing symptomology is associated with reduced cortical thinning in the orbitofrontal cortex and increased externalizing symptomology is associated with reduced thinning in the postcentral gyrus.

attributes.title: The Effect of Instructors’ Cold Calling on Students' Attention and Learning

q1.value: The Effect of Instructors’ Cold Calling on Students' Attention and Learning

q3.value: The goal of this research is to examine the effect of instructors’ cold calling on students' attention and learning. Cold calling within the context of teaching is a technique involving randomly calling on a student to answer a question or solve a problem during class. Presumably, teachers do so because they believe that this strategy is effective in motivating their students to pay attention to the material that are teaching and to effectively encode that material. In this experiment, we will test the hypothesis that students who anticipate being cold called during a lecture will pay more attention to the lecture (and learn more from the lecture) relative to students who do not expect to be cold called. Additionally, we will explore the possibility that the effectiveness of cold calling may depend on the extent to which a student experiences performance anxiety. Students with high performance anxiety may be particularly likely to pay attention and effectively learn the lecture material in the cold calling condition because they are motivated to avoid embarrassing themselves by not knowing the answer to the question. Alternately, students with high performance anxiety may be too anxious to effectively pay attention and learn the lecture material.

q4.value: We hypothesize that the participants who believe that they will be called upon at some point during the experiment will pay more attention to the lecture materials in order to correctly answer the question when called upon by the researcher. We also hypothesize that participants who expect to be called on will perform better on a multiple-choice test of lecture content.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Groups of 12-24 participants will be seated in a simulated classroom environment and will be told by the experiment that they will be watching a 48-minute lecture video on the history of Pompeii (an abridged version of a Yale lecture video that is publicly available on YouTube; please see https://oyc.yale.edu/history-art/hsar-252/lecture-4).  Participants will be told that their task is to learn the content of the video, which they will subsequently be tested on. The experimenter will be present in the classroom during the lecture video.  This study will utilize a between subject design, where participants are randomly assigned to the cold calling condition or the control condition. In the cold calling condition, participants will be told that the video will pause at some point during the lecture (randomly determined), and the experimenter will ask them a question regarding the lecture that will they will answer vocally. Participants in the control call not expect to be asked a question during the lecture. The lecture video will pause (approximately every 3 minutes) and participants will be asked to rate their attentiveness. Participants will initially be told that the lecture video is 48-minutes, but after 36 minutes the experimenter will stop the video and will indicate that there will be a multiple-choice test before continuing.   After the multiple-choice test, participants will be informed that the experiment is over.  This is followed by Post-lecture Questionnaire (assessing participants’ level of attention, motivation and anxiety while watching the video) and Demographic Questionnaire. The deceptive elements of the experiment will then be acknowledged during a debriefing phase of the experiment. Participants will have 8 minutes to finish a multiple-choice quiz .

q9.value: Participants are randomly assigned to either control or cold calling condition.  We will alternate between the two conditions at each seat in the room.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will be recruiting participants from the McMaster participant pool (who are taking Introductory Psychology).  There are no exclusion criteria within that group.

q13.value: If the subject pool is sufficiently robust, then we will run approximately 180 participants in this study (90 in each condition).

q15.value: Since we are running participants in large groups, it is unlikely that we will end up with exactly 180 participants.  165-190 participants.

question.value: Participants in the cold calling condition are told that they will be called upon randomly once to answer a question during the course of the lecture. Conversely, in the control condition participants are not expecting to be called upon at any time during the lecture.

The dependent variables for both control and cold call condition includes the following:
1. A questionnaire that periodically asks participants about their rate of attentiveness during the lecture (approximately every 2-4 minutes, with 12 ratings in total). Participants respond on a scale that ranges from zero to ten, where zero corresponds with a lack of attevtinvess and ten corresponds with being extremely attentive. 
2. A 4-option multiple choice test composed of twelve questions that assesses participants knowledge of the lecture material. 
3. A Post-lecture questionnaire to assess participants’ level of attention, motivation and anxiety while watching the video, and also includes a manipulation check measure that asks participants whether they expected to be called on at some point during the course of the lecture. This is finally followed by a demographic questionnaire that collects information about participants’ age, gender and ethnic background (for exploratory purposes).

Main analyses:
In order to test our first hypothesis regarding participant attention levels, we plan to use MLM (because each participant will be rating their attentiveness at several time points across the lecture).  We will also report the more straightforward analysis of averaging attentiveness ratings across the 12 time points and then comparing the mean attentiveness ratings across conditions using a two-tailed independent samples t-test (with a significance criterion of alpha < .05).  In order to test our second hypothesis regarding participant scores on the final multiple choice test, we will average test scores across the two conditions and report two-tailed independent samples t-tests.
Secondary analyses:
--Additionally, based on prior research, we expect to find a positive association between attentiveness and test performance (in each condition and overall).
--Based on prior research, we also expect that self-reported attentiveness will decrease over the course of the lecture (in each condition and overall)
--Further, we expected that students in the cold-calling condition will report higher levels of anxiety than those in the control condition.

q22.value:
Participants’ will be excluded for the following reasons:
Failing to answer more than 50% of the attention ratings during the lecture (non-compliance).
Failing to answer all of the multiple-choice questions (non-compliance).
Failing to answer one or more questions on the post-lecture questionnaire (non-compliance).
If the manipulation check reveals that participants did not read or understand the study instructions.  That is, if participants in the cold-calling condition indicate that they did not expect to be called on and participants in the control condition indicate that they did expect to be called on.

q23.value: Missing data will be left blank.  Participants will be excluded for having too much missing data (according to the criteria outlined above).

q24.value: We will explore the possibility that the effectiveness of cold calling may depend on the extent to which a student experiences performance anxiety. Students with high performance anxiety may be particularly likely to pay attention and effectively learn the lecture material in the cold calling condition because they are motivated to avoid embarrassing themselves by not knowing the answer to the question. Alternately, students with high performance anxiety may be too anxious to effectively pay attention and learn the lecture material.  To assess these possibilities we will perform a variety of exploratory analyses that will test whether (1) participants were more motivated in the cold calling condition than in the control condition, (2) participants were more anxious in the cold calling condition than in the control condition, (3) higher levels of motivation were associated with higher level attentiveness and better test performance, (4) higher levels of anxiety were associated with higher (or lower) levels of attentiveness and better (or worse) test performance (perhaps there is a quadratic function).  Relatedly, we will explore whether motivation mediates the relation between our experimental manipulation and attentiveness.

registration_responses.q1: The Effect of Instructors’ Cold Calling on Students' Attention and Learning
registration_responses.q3: The goal of this research is to examine the effect of instructors’ cold calling on students' attention and learning. Cold calling within the context of teaching is a technique involving randomly calling on a student to answer a question or solve a problem during class. Presumably, teachers do so because they believe that this strategy is effective in motivating their students to pay attention to the material that are teaching and to effectively encode that material. In this experiment, we will test the hypothesis that students who anticipate being cold called during a lecture will pay more attention to the lecture (and learn more from the lecture) relative to students who do not expect to be cold called. Additionally, we will explore the possibility that the effectiveness of cold calling may depend on the extent to which a student experiences performance anxiety. Students with high performance anxiety may be particularly likely to pay attention and effectively learn the lecture material in the cold calling condition because they are motivated to avoid embarrassing themselves by not knowing the answer to the question. Alternately, students with high performance anxiety may be too anxious to effectively pay attention and learn the lecture material.
registration_responses.q4: We hypothesize that the participants who believe that they will be called upon at some point during the experiment will pay more attention to the lecture materials in order to correctly answer the question when called upon by the researcher. We also hypothesize that participants who expect to be called on will perform better on a multiple-choice test of lecture content.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: Participants are randomly assigned to either control or cold calling condition.  We will alternate between the two conditions at each seat in the room.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: If the subject pool is sufficiently robust, then we will run approximately 180 participants in this study (90 in each condition).
registration_responses.q15: Since we are running participants in large groups, it is unlikely that we will end up with exactly 180 participants.  165-190 participants.
registration_responses.q22:
Participants’ will be excluded for the following reasons:
Failing to answer more than 50% of the attention ratings during the lecture (non-compliance).
Failing to answer all of the multiple-choice questions (non-compliance).
Failing to answer one or more questions on the post-lecture questionnaire (non-compliance).
If the manipulation check reveals that participants did not read or understand the study instructions.  That is, if participants in the cold-calling condition indicate that they did not expect to be called on and participants in the control condition indicate that they did expect to be called on.
registration_responses.q23: Missing data will be left blank.  Participants will be excluded for having too much missing data (according to the criteria outlined above).
registration_responses.q24: We will explore the possibility that the effectiveness of cold calling may depend on the extent to which a student experiences performance anxiety. Students with high performance anxiety may be particularly likely to pay attention and effectively learn the lecture material in the cold calling condition because they are motivated to avoid embarrassing themselves by not knowing the answer to the question. Alternately, students with high performance anxiety may be too anxious to effectively pay attention and learn the lecture material.  To assess these possibilities we will perform a variety of exploratory analyses that will test whether (1) participants were more motivated in the cold calling condition than in the control condition, (2) participants were more anxious in the cold calling condition than in the control condition, (3) higher levels of motivation were associated with higher level attentiveness and better test performance, (4) higher levels of anxiety were associated with higher (or lower) levels of attentiveness and better (or worse) test performance (perhaps there is a quadratic function).  Relatedly, we will explore whether motivation mediates the relation between our experimental manipulation and attentiveness.
registration_responses.q8.question: Groups of 12-24 participants will be seated in a simulated classroom environment and will be told by the experiment that they will be watching a 48-minute lecture video on the history of Pompeii (an abridged version of a Yale lecture video that is publicly available on YouTube; please see https://oyc.yale.edu/history-art/hsar-252/lecture-4).  Participants will be told that their task is to learn the content of the video, which they will subsequently be tested on. The experimenter will be present in the classroom during the lecture video.  This study will utilize a between subject design, where participants are randomly assigned to the cold calling condition or the control condition. In the cold calling condition, participants will be told that the video will pause at some point during the lecture (randomly determined), and the experimenter will ask them a question regarding the lecture that will they will answer vocally. Participants in the control call not expect to be asked a question during the lecture. The lecture video will pause (approximately every 3 minutes) and participants will be asked to rate their attentiveness. Participants will initially be told that the lecture video is 48-minutes, but after 36 minutes the experimenter will stop the video and will indicate that there will be a multiple-choice test before continuing.   After the multiple-choice test, participants will be informed that the experiment is over.  This is followed by Post-lecture Questionnaire (assessing participants’ level of attention, motivation and anxiety while watching the video) and Demographic Questionnaire. The deceptive elements of the experiment will then be acknowledged during a debriefing phase of the experiment. Participants will have 8 minutes to finish a multiple-choice quiz .
registration_responses.q12.question: We will be recruiting participants from the McMaster participant pool (who are taking Introductory Psychology).  There are no exclusion criteria within that group.
registration_responses.q16.question: Participants in the cold calling condition are told that they will be called upon randomly once to answer a question during the course of the lecture. Conversely, in the control condition participants are not expecting to be called upon at any time during the lecture.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The dependent variables for both control and cold call condition includes the following:
1. A questionnaire that periodically asks participants about their rate of attentiveness during the lecture (approximately every 2-4 minutes, with 12 ratings in total). Participants respond on a scale that ranges from zero to ten, where zero corresponds with a lack of attevtinvess and ten corresponds with being extremely attentive. 
2. A 4-option multiple choice test composed of twelve questions that assesses participants knowledge of the lecture material. 
3. A Post-lecture questionnaire to assess participants’ level of attention, motivation and anxiety while watching the video, and also includes a manipulation check measure that asks participants whether they expected to be called on at some point during the course of the lecture. This is finally followed by a demographic questionnaire that collects information about participants’ age, gender and ethnic background (for exploratory purposes).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Main analyses:
In order to test our first hypothesis regarding participant attention levels, we plan to use MLM (because each participant will be rating their attentiveness at several time points across the lecture).  We will also report the more straightforward analysis of averaging attentiveness ratings across the 12 time points and then comparing the mean attentiveness ratings across conditions using a two-tailed independent samples t-test (with a significance criterion of alpha < .05).  In order to test our second hypothesis regarding participant scores on the final multiple choice test, we will average test scores across the two conditions and report two-tailed independent samples t-tests.
Secondary analyses:
--Additionally, based on prior research, we expect to find a positive association between attentiveness and test performance (in each condition and overall).
--Based on prior research, we also expect that self-reported attentiveness will decrease over the course of the lecture (in each condition and overall)
--Further, we expected that students in the cold-calling condition will report higher levels of anxiety than those in the control condition.
